newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Cheap imports create chilli glut in Sri Lanka.
newsitem.headline: Cheap imports create chilli glut in Sri Lanka.

text.p: Sri Lankan farmers were stuck with more than 50,000 tonnes of dried chillies as prices for the hot commodity slid sharply due to cheaper imports, the state-owned Daily News said on Friday.
The price of chillies, used extensively in spicey Sri Lankan dishes, has come down to 40 rupees ($0.68) per kg from 90 rupees per kg a few months ago, the paper said.
Current prices did not even cover local farmers' cost of production, it said.
"The price of dried chillies has dropped sharply in the Colombo market due to imports from India by the private sector," it added.
About two weeks ago, farmers in the island's chilli-growing north-central region burnt some of their harvest in a public protest to demand a guaranteed-price scheme for their produce.
But government officials responsible for purchasing farmers' produce told Reuters that farmers were asking for premium prices when cheaper imports were available in the market.
"We don't have price controls for chillies. Anyone can import chillies and sell it at whatever price they wish," one official said.
"Naturally, when there are chillies available in the market for 40-50 rupees, the government can't buy from farmers at higer prices," he said.
